title: Live updates: Trump says Iran and Israel have agreed to ceasefire and end to their war
description: Iran launched missiles at al-Udeid Air Base Monday. Qatar said it intercepted the strike and the Pentagon said it was not aware of any U.S. casualties.
author: Niha Masih, Andrew Jeong, Abbie Cheeseman, Angie Orellana Hernandez, Joshua Yang, Adam Taylor
byline: Niha Masih, Andrew Jeong, Abbie Cheeseman, Angie Orellana Hernandez, Joshua Yang, Adam Taylor, Mustafa Salim, Warren P. Strobel, Souad Mekhennet, Yeganeh Torbati, Rachel Pannett, Evan Halper, Ellen Francis, Cate Brown, Amy B Wang, Marianna Sotomayor, Andrew deGrandpre, Brian Perlman, Aaron Gregg, Mariana Alfaro, Janice Kai Chen, Alex Horton, Erin Cunningham, Susannah George, Greg Miller, Hannah Knowles, Cat Zakrzewski, Clara Ence Morse, Annabelle Timsit, Patrick Svitek, Maham Javaid, Lior Soroka, Claire Parker, Natalie Allison, Michael Birnbaum, Theodoric Meyer, Azi Paybarah, Joshua Partlow, Natalia Abbakumova, Meg Kelly, Joyce Sohyun Lee, Nilo Tabrizy, Evan Hill, Dylan Moriarty, Ishaan Tharoor, Mohamad El Chamaa, HyoJung Kim, Sammy Westfall, Steve Hendrix
excerpt: Iran launched missiles at al-Udeid Air Base Monday. Qatar said it intercepted the strike and the Pentagon said it was not aware of any U.S. casualties.
text: President Donald Trump said in an announcement on social media that Iran and Israel had agreed to a ceasefire, ending what he said should be called the “12-day war.” He congratulated both countries, saying the conflict “could have gone on for years, and destroyed the entire Middle East.” There was no immediate corroborating announcement from either the Israeli or Iranian governments. In an earlier post on Truth Social, Trump downplayed an Iranian attack Monday on the forward headquarters for U.S. Central Command in Qatar, home to about 10,000 troops, as a “very weak response” by Tehran to U.S. strikes on key Iranian nuclear sites. The president said there were no deaths or injuries in the attack.Missiles were seen in the Qatari capital on June 23 following Tehran's threat to retaliate for U.S. airstrikes. (Video: The Washington Post)Live coverage contributors 49Return to menuVice President JD Vance on Fox News said President Donald Trump had been “working the phones constantly” over the past 12 days of war between Israel and Iran. Vance said the ceasefire was in the works when he left the White House for the broadcast but that the American objective was to ensure Iran could not build a nuclear weapon. “I actually think when we look back, we will say the twelve-day war was an important reset moment for the entire region,” he said.Return to menuCamp Taji, which hosts U.S. service members in central Iraq, came under drone attack, according to two Iraqi officials. The extent of the damage or casualties was not immediately known.Exclusive: Israel warned top Iranian general, officials amid June 13 strikesReturn to menuIn the hours after Israel launched its first wave of strikes against Iran on June 13, killing top military leaders and nuclear scientists, Israeli intelligence operatives launched a covert campaign to intimidate senior officials with the apparent aim of dividing and destabilizing Tehran’s theocratic regime, according to three people familiar with the operation.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuPresident Donald Trump said on social media that Iran and Israel have agreed to a ceasefire, ending what he said should be called the “12-day war.” He congratulated both countries, saying the conflict “could have gone on for years, and destroyed the entire Middle East.” There was no immediate corroborating announcement from either the Israeli or Iranian governments, and his announcement followed a streak of social media posts Monday evening in which he thanked Iran for giving the U.S. advance warning of a missile attack on a U.S. air base in Qatar, while also calling it a “very weak response” in retaliation for U.S. strikes on key Iranian nuclear facilities. A day ago, he floated the possibility of “regime change” in Iran in a late night post.Oil prices plunge as Iran retaliates with attack on U.S. air baseReturn to menuOil prices plunged on Monday afternoon as markets reacted to Iran’s decision to retaliate for the U.S. bombing by striking a military target in Qatar rather than trying to close the Strait of Hormuz.Some 20 percent of the world’s oil and gas flows through the narrow strait. Iran had threatened to try to close it to shipping traffic, a move that could send oil prices soaring and push prices at the pump in the United States above $4 per gallon.Return to menuIn a string of social media posts on Monday, President Donald Trump appeared to signal a de-escalation of tensions with Iran, writing that Tehran seems to have “gotten it all out of their ‘system’” with its telegraphed and limited attack on U.S. forces in Qatar, and encouraging Iran and Israel to seek “Peace and Harmony in the Region.” “CONGRATULATIONS WORLD, IT’S TIME FOR PEACE!” he wrote in one Truth Social message.Return to menuPresident Donald Trump described Iran’s missile attack on a U.S. air base in Qatar as a “very weak response” in retaliation for U.S. strikes on key Iranian nuclear sites. Trump said on Truth Social Monday that Iran gave the U.S. early warning, which “made it possible for no lives to be lost, and nobody to be injured.”Macron says ‘no legality to’ U.S. strikes on IranReturn to menuFrench President Emmanuel Macron on Monday diverged from other key U.S. allies, saying there was “no legality to” the U.S. strikes on Iran, even if France “shares the objective” of preventing Tehran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. “We have consistently believed this can only be achieved through diplomatic and technical means,” Macron said. Other officials emphasized that France had no role in the strikes or the planning.This is an excerpt from a full story.In attack on Iran’s Evin prison, Israel struck a symbol of the regimeReturn to menuAn Israeli airstrike Monday destroyed the front gate of Iran’s notorious Evin prison and caused other damage to the complex, according to state media reports and footage from the scene.Schumer, Jeffries demand classified briefing after Iran’s counterattackReturn to menuDemocrats in the Gang of Eight — the nickname for the eight congressional leaders the executive branch is required by statute to brief on classified intelligence — are demanding a classified briefing after reports that Iran is launching counterattacks on U.S. military bases in the Middle East to retaliate against the strikes on its nuclear facilities this weekend.Trump heralded Iran diplomacy in al-Udeid appearance just weeks agoReturn to menuOnly a few weeks ago, President Donald Trump made a highly publicized appearance at al-Udeid Air Base — the military facility in Qatar that Iran targeted Monday with ballistic missiles — where he touted his administration’s diplomatic efforts to curtail Tehran’s nuclear ambitions.With hundreds of uniformed service members as a backdrop, the president gave an address focused, in part, on his sense of optimism that those negotiations would win out with Iran.Return to menuVideo filmed from central Doha, Qatar, verified by The Washington Post, appears to show air defenses intercepting Iranian missiles bound for al-Udeid Air Base late Monday.Middle Eastern countries denounce Iranian strikes in QatarReturn to menuEgypt, Jordan, Bahrain, Oman, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates were among the Middle Eastern countries that expressed support for Qatar in the aftermath of an Iranian missile strike against a U.S. military base outside the Qatari capital, Doha.In separate statements, most of the countries denounced growing military escalation in the region and called for peace and diplomacy.Oil prices drop as investors downplay risk of oil-market disruptionReturn to menuOil prices tumbled Monday afternoon after Iran fired missiles at a U.S. military base in Qatar, in what one energy market analyst described as a “deliberately mild” response to American strikes against Iranian nuclear sites the day before.Speaker Mike Johnson says he’s against vote on war powers resolution Return to menuHouse Speaker Mike Johnson (R-Louisiana) said Monday he’s not interested in voting on a measure that would reaffirm Congress’s right to declare war.Return to menuThe Israel Defense Forces said it carried out the most extensive wave of strikes in Tehran on Monday since attacks began June 13.Military spokesman Avichay Adraee said on X that the IDF targeted facilities connected to Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps.Return to menuIn his first statement since Iran launched missiles at a U.S. base in Qatar, President Donald Trump did not mention the Iranian strike and criticized the media for reporting that the Iranian nuclear sites, which the U.S. targeted Sunday, may not have been destroyed. “The sites that we hit in Iran were totally destroyed, and everyone knows it,” he wrote in a Truth Social post.Jeffries says Trump must explain how U.S. will avoid being ‘dragged’ into warReturn to menuHouse Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-New York), in a “Dear Colleague” letter sent Monday to members of the House Democratic Caucus, said the Trump administration must justify its decision to bomb Iranian nuclear facilities over the weekend and must also explain how the United States will avoid “being dragged into another prolonged war in the Middle East.”Return to menuA video posted to social media shows apparent missile interceptions in the skies over Doha on June 23. (Video: Michael Stephens)A video taken from The Pearl, an artificial island near Qatar’s capital, Doha, appears to show missile interceptions over the city. Return to menuIraq and Kuwait both announced that they were closing their airspace Monday, following an Iranian missile attack aimed at a U.S. air base in Qatar. Kuwaiti authorities said the closure was a precautionary measure and did not say whether there was a specific threat. Qatar and Bahrain also temporarily suspended air traffic Monday.Return to menuReporting from the PentagonThe Pentagon is not aware of any U.S. injuries or deaths resulting from Iran’s attack on Al-Udeid Air Base in Qatar, U.S. defense officials said, acknowledging the strike involved short-range and medium-range ballistic missiles.Qatar’s Defense Ministry said in a statement that Qatari air defenses had intercepted the missiles and affirmed the incident ended with no deaths or injuries.Return to menuIran's military said on June 23 that it carried out a missile attack on al-Udeid Air Base in Qatar. (Video: Reuters)Soon after Iran fired missiles at Qatar, neighboring Bahrain said it was suspending air traffic as a precautionary measure “in light of the evolving regional situation.” Air raid sirens also sounded in the country, the interior ministry said late Monday, urging residents to find the nearest safe place.Return to menuAl-Udeid Air Base holds the largest U.S. contingent in the Middle East. The base, which is owned by Qatar and located 20 miles southwest of the capital, Doha, is a forward command post for U.S. Central Command, the military combatant command with overall responsibility for the Middle East, and can house more than 10,000 troops.Return to menu“As we hear reports of missile attacks by the Iranian Regime against U.S. forces in the Middle East, we pray fervently for the safety of our brave service members in the region,” Rep. Tom Emmer (R-Minnesota), the third-ranking Republican in the U.S. House of Representatives, wrote on X.Return to menuQatar condemned Iran’s strikes targeting the American Al-Udeid Air Base, just southwest of the Qatari capital, Doha, as a “flagrant violation” of Qatar’s “sovereignty and airspace, as well as of international law and the United Nations Charter,” Qatari spokesman Majed al-Ansari posted on X.The Iranian missiles were intercepted and the base was evacuated beforehand, al-Ansari said. No injuries have been reported.Pentagon spokespeople said they were monitoring the situation and did not provide more information.Iran said it launched strikes against U.S. base in QatarReturn to menuIran said it launched retaliatory strikes against a U.S. base in Qatar on Monday, according to a statement from the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps.Iran “launched a powerful and devastating missile assault” against al-Udeid Air Base, the largest U.S. base in the Middle East and the home of U.S. Central Command’s forward headquarters, the statement said.Explosions were heard over Doha, according to a Western diplomat who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive matters.Fordow damage expected to be significant, IAEA chief saysReturn to menuBEIRUT — The U.S. attacks on Iran’s deeply buried Fordow enrichment site are expected to have caused “very significant” damage, according to the head of the United Nations nuclear watchdog, who called for a “cessation of hostilities” so that inspectors can assess the situation in Iran.A weakened Iran could turn to assassination and terrorism to strike back Return to menuThe American bombing of Iranian nuclear facilities pushed the U.S. conflict with Iran across a dangerous new threshold. U.S. and Western security officials said that they expect Iran to seek to retaliate in ways that eclipse its attempts to avenge the death of Quds leader Qasem Soleimani, and that the United States and its allies in Europe and the Middle East face an escalated threat from Iran that could last years.This is an excerpt from a full story.Qatar closes airspace, Foreign Ministry saysReturn to menuQatar has closed its airspace and suspended flights to “ensure the safety of citizens, residents and visitors,” the Qatari Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Monday in a post to X.The ministry said it was a “precautionary measure” as the region braces for potential wider war.Rep. Greene says Trump’s decision to strike Iran ‘feels like a complete bait and switch’Return to menuRep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Georgia), who had been among the far-right conservatives urging President Donald Trump not to get further involved militarily in the war between Israel and Iran, on Monday escalated her criticism of Trump’s decision to strike Iran’s nuclear facilities.Closing the Strait of Hormuz could punish China, a close partner to IranReturn to menuIf Iran closes the Strait of Hormuz, a critical shipping waterway in the Persian Gulf, China, one of Iran’s closest partners, would be hit hard by the economic impact.Here’s what else to knowReturn to menuPresident Donald Trump — who is slated to meet with his national security team Monday afternoon — raised the prospect of regime change in Tehran, undercutting the messaging from his top officials. He also continued to claim substantial damage to the nuclear facilities from U.S. strikes, without providing additional evidence. The International Atomic Energy Agency is assessing the damage.The Israeli military launched “unprecedentedly powerful” strikes Monday against an expanded set of targets across Iran, the Israeli Defense Ministry said. Sirens also sounded across Israel on Monday morning as Iran launched another salvo. There were no immediate reports of casualties.Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi met with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow. Russia has shied away from providing Tehran with military assistance as Israel continues to pound Iran’s nuclear and military infrastructure. Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Esmaeil Baqaei said Iran expects Russia to play an active role at a time of conflict between Tehran and Washington, citing a strategic partnership that Tehran and Moscow signed just months ago — which Moscow has sought to downplay since the conflict began. The meeting at the Kremlin was scheduled before the U.S. attacks on Iran.Iranian Maj. Gen. Abdolrahim Mousavi, chief of the Iranian army’s Joint Staff, warned Washington that the strikes on its nuclear facilities were tantamount to invading the country and have given Tehran a “free hand” to “act against U.S. interests and its army,” according to Iran’s official Islamic Republic News Agency.MAGA is divided over Trump’s decision to bomb Iran. Will it last?Return to menuPresident Donald Trump’s decision to attack three nuclear sites in Iran this weekend has divided supporters and unsettled some allies of his “America First” movement who embraced his campaign-trail promises to “expel the warmongers from our government.”Republican leaders largely rallied behind the president after the strikes, but the notes of dissent were striking in a party usually in lockstep with Trump.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuThe Israel Defense Forces cautioned Tehran residents to “stay away from weapons production centers, military headquarters, and security institutions affiliated with the regime” as more strikes are anticipated in the coming days.Israel intensified its strikes against Iran on Monday, using more than 50 Air Force fighter jets to attack targets in Tehran, the IDF said on X.Hundreds killed in Iran and Israel as war continues, officials sayReturn to menuHundreds of people have died in the war between Israel and Iran — most of them in Iran — as the countries continued trading fire Monday for the 11th day.The Human Rights Activists News Agency, a Washington-based rights group that monitors Iran, said 950 people have been killed in Israeli strikes on Iran and 3,450 injured as of Sunday at 9 p.m. local time. The group uses local sources to collate casualty reports.White House: Position on regime change in Iran hasn’t changedReturn to menuThe White House contended Monday that its position on regime change in Iran has not changed, a day after President Donald Trump raised the issue in a social media post.During an interview on Fox News, White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt suggested that Trump believes the Iranian people — not the United States — should drive any regime change in their country following the U.S. attack on three nuclear sites there.What is the Massive Ordnance Penetrator, the U.S. bunker-busting bomb?Return to menuB-2 Stealth bombers were seen arriving at Whiteman Air Force Base in Missouri on June 22, hours after the U.S. attack on Iranian nuclear facilities. (Video: AP)The signature weapons employed in the U.S. military’s predawn strike on Iran were 30,000-pound precision-guided “bunker busters” designed exclusively to destroy underground targets.U.S. strategic bombers dropped 14 of the munitions in the mission to degrade Iran’s nuclear program, top Pentagon officials said Sunday. The GBU-57s, or the Massive Ordnance Penetrator (MOP for short), were carried by a fleet of B-2 bombers, the first time the munitions were used in combat.This is an excerpt from a full story.Australia backs U.S. strikes on Iran, after initial cautionReturn to menuAustralia on Monday expressed support for the U.S. strikes on Iran, in remarks from its prime minister and foreign minister that went a step further from the government’s more cautious stance the previous day.Prime Minister Anthony Albanese told reporters that Australia supports action preventing Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons, the Australian Broadcasting Corp., the country’s public broadcaster, reported.Several impacts but no casualties in Monday missile strikes, IDF saysReturn to menuMissiles launched from Iran toward Israel on Monday made “several impacts with no casualties,” Israel Defense Forces spokesman Effie Defrin said during a news briefing.Return to menuIsrael struck the entrances to the Fordow nuclear enrichment site Monday to prevent the transfer of materials, an Israeli official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive military operations. The crisis management agency of Qom province, where Fordow is located, told the semiofficial Tasnim News Agency the plant had come under renewed attack, this time from Israeli jets. The United States hit the heavily fortified site Sunday, and the damage is still being assessed.Video published by IRNA, the official news agency of Iran, on June 22 showed smoke rising from the Fordow nuclear enrichment facility. (Video: IRNA)Middle East is ‘waiting to see what Iran will do’Return to menuIn the rest of the Middle East, “everybody is waiting to see what Iran will do,” said Hesham Youssef, a retired Egyptian diplomat. “Everybody is feeling that the ball now is in Iran’s court, as far as what kind of response, both on the military level and even more importantly, on the strategic level. Will the response be an angry response? Or a response that has more of a strategic perspective?”“With the American attack, that’s a new dimension and a new ballgame,” Youssef said.Return to menuIsraeli strikes have cut power to parts of northern Tehran, according to the semiofficial Mehr News Agency, just hours after an Iranian missile hit near what Israeli officials described as a “strategic infrastructure facility” in southern Israel that disrupted power to 8,000 households. Citing a statement from Tavanir, Iran’s national electric company, Mehr said one of the main power lines supplying northern Tehran was damaged and electricity was cut in parts of Districts 2 and 3.Return to menuThe U.S. Embassy in Doha, home to the Middle East’s largest U.S. base, has issued an urgent security warning to Americans in Qatar telling them to shelter in place until further notice “out of an abundance of caution.” Iran has said U.S. military bases in the region could be a target in its expected retaliation after the United States hit Iranian nuclear sites. Al-Udeid Air Base, outside of Doha, is the forward headquarters for U.S. Central Command and is home to about 10,000 troops.Putin meets with Iran’s foreign minister, calls for solution to ‘get out’ of war Return to menuRussian President Vladimir Putin condemned U.S. and Israeli strikes on Iran during a Monday meeting in Moscow with Iran’s foreign minister and said it was important to find a way out of current tensions.Israel expands scope of attacks in Iran as Tehran weighs its responseReturn to menuBEIRUT — Israel said Monday that it was striking targets linked to Iranian “state oppression,” expanding the scope of its attacks to symbols such as the country’s notorious Evin Prison in a deviation from its stated war aims of degrading Tehran’s nuclear and ballistic missile programs and any existential threats to Israel.How Trump got to ‘yes’ on bombing Iran Return to menuFor days, President Donald Trump played coy about his plans to strike Iran, declaring that he hadn’t yet made up his mind even as he approved attack plans and directed military officials to ready their forces.Within a small circle of White House and administration officials, it was clear that even when Trump announced Thursday that he might take as long as “two weeks” to decide, an attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities was imminent, and the ruse was already underway.This is an excerpt from a full story.Democrats, some Republicans question Trump’s unilateral attack Return to menuPresident Donald Trump’s decision to send U.S. forces to strike Iran without consulting Congress is prompting bipartisan unease among lawmakers, with most Democrats and a handful of Republicans questioning the accuracy of military intelligence behind the attack as well as the constitutionality of the president’s actions.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuPresident Donald Trump will meet his national security team on Monday afternoon, according to a schedule released by the White House. Trump in a Truth Social post Sunday evening suggested the possibility of regime change in Iran, after top officials including Vice President JD Vance said the administration wasn’t interested in such a move.What is the Strait of Hormuz? Iran weighs closing key waterway for global trade.Return to menuAs Iran weights a response to U.S. strikes, Iranian media reported that the country’s parliament endorsed the closure of the Strait of Hormuz, a crucial choke point for the world’s oil supply, with the ultimate decision in the hands of the country’s top leaders.White House releases Situation Room photos from when U.S. struck Iran sitesReturn to menuAfter President Donald Trump launched the first significant U.S. military intervention on Iranian soil since the 1979 overthrow of the U.S.-backed shah of Iran, the White House released photos of the president and his top advisers in the Situation Room. The photos, which have been viewed nearly 10 million times on X, were digitally altered, potentially to obscure sensitive or classified material. According to the Associated Press, some papers “have been blurred by the source.”This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuNorth Korea’s Foreign Ministry denounced the U.S. airstrikes on Iran in a statement Monday, saying the attack violated Iran’s sovereignty and international law, and blamed Israel and the West for the current crisis in the Middle East. North Korea withdrew from the nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty in 2003 and conducted its first nuclear weapons test in 2006.Return to menuIsrael appears to be escalating its strikes in Iran on Monday morning, with the Israeli military and Iranian media reporting several waves of attacks across Iran. Israeli Defense Minister Israel Katz said the military “is currently striking with unprecedented force at regime targets and government repression institutions in the heart of Tehran.” Iran’s semiofficial Tasnim News Agency reported that Israel hit the Fordow nuclear site, which the United States struck Sunday. The report could not immediately be verified.Return to menuAsked what Russia was prepared to do to help Tehran, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said at a news conference before Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi’s meeting with President Vladimir Putin that it “depends on what Iran needs.” He also sidestepped a question on whether Russia was ready to supply weapons to Iran, saying it would depend on what “our Iranian friends” say. Peskov reiterated Russia’s offer to mediate between Israel and Iran, saying: “This is a kind of support for the Iranian side.”Iran says ‘all options’ on table; bigger conflict may threaten regime’s survival Return to menuDUBAI — After a U.S. attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities, Iran is weighing its response — with its top diplomat saying “all options” are on the table after Washington proved “they only understand the language of threat and force.” The United States “opted for a dangerous military operation and aggression against the people of Iran,” Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi said Sunday, and he separately warned of “everlasting consequences.”This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuDmitry Medvedev, deputy chairman of Russia’s Security Council and the country’s former president, said the Trump administration’s strikes on Iranian nuclear sites would only strengthen Tehran’s regime and bolster global opposition to the Israeli and American governments. “Donald Trump, once hailed as ‘president of peace,’ has now pushed the US into another war,” Medvedev wrote Sunday.Return to menuAn Iranian ballistic missile hit “near a strategic infrastructure facility” and caused power disruptions across parts of southern Israel, the Israel Electric Corporation said in a statement Monday. About 8,000 homes and businesses are without electricity, Energy Minister Eli Cohen said in a video statement sent to The Washington Post. “We prepared in advance for the possibility of damage to power facilities,” he said, adding that he expected power to be restored within three hours.Iran’s foreign minister says he will discuss ‘common threats’ with PutinReturn to menuIran’s Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi said he will discuss “confronting common challenges and threats” with Russian President Vladimir Putin at a meeting later Monday, according to Iran’s official Islamic Republic News Agency.What satellite images show of damage to Iran’s nuclear sites Return to menuSatellite images provide the first glimpses of the aftermath of U.S. strikes on three sites said to be central to Iran’s nuclear program, revealing severe damage at aboveground facilities as well as the entry points left by bombs that burrowed deep underground to target some of the program’s most protected operations.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuIranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi arrived in Moscow on Monday for talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin, Russian and Iranian state media reported. The meeting was scheduled prior to the U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear sites.“We have worked and consulted together on every issue and coordinated our positions. Now, certain conditions prevail in the region that require our positions to be more precise, serious and closer,” Araghchi told reporters as he landed, according to Iran’s semiofficial Mehr News Agency. He said he hopes Russia will take “practical steps” to support Iran at the U.N. Security Council and other international forums.Analysis: Trump bombs Iran, raising the ghosts of IraqReturn to menuReturn to menuMissiles were launched toward Israel early Monday, the Israel Defense Forces said. Air raid sirens sounded in the north and center of the country, including around the Golan Heights, Haifa and Jerusalem. The IDF said in a statement that the Iron Dome missile defense system was working to identify and intercept the threats.Return to menuIn a security alert, the State Department advised U.S. citizens worldwide to “exercise increased caution” in light of the conflict between Israel and Iran. “There is the potential for demonstrations against U.S. citizens and interests abroad,” it said. The alert was issued a day after U.S. airstrikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities.Return to menuIran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps warned Sunday that the United States should expect a response to its attacks on the country’s nuclear facilities, describing any retaliation as “legitimate self-defense.”“The bases and locations used by the forces that carried out the attacks have been identified,” the IRGC, Iran’s most powerful military and security force, said in a statement, calling the U.S. presence in the region “a point of weakness that increases the enemy’s vulnerability.”Vance: Iran retaliating would be ‘the stupidest thing’ Return to menuVice President JD Vance, on NBC's “Meet The Press” on June 22, urged Iran not to retaliate, saying it would be “the stupidest thing.” (Video: NBC News)U.S. embassies in region urge increased cautionReturn to menuU.S. embassies across the Middle East issued updated alerts to U.S. government personnel and American citizens on Sunday, urging them to maintain low profiles, increase caution and in some cases leave the country.The State Department on Sunday ordered Lebanon-based nonemergency U.S. government personnel and family members to leave the country “due to the volatile and unpredictable security situation in the region.”Return to menuIsraeli drones struck six Iranian airports, destroying 15 Iranian fighter jets and helicopters, a spokesperson for the Israel Defense Forces said. In a separate statement on Monday, the IDF said it had hit runways, underground hangars, a refueling aircraft, F-14 and F-5 fighter jets, AH-1 aircraft and helicopters.Return to menuIn an address to the nation, President Donald Trump, speaking from the White House on June 21, said U.S. warplanes had struck three Iranian nuclear facilities. (Video: The Washington Post)President Donald Trump repeated his claims about the extent of damage caused by U.S. airstrikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities, without providing additional evidence. “Monumental Damage was done to all Nuclear sites in Iran, as shown by satellite images. Obliteration is an accurate term!” he said Sunday night on social media. U.S. officials have said the airstrikes caused severe damage, corroborated by satellite images that provide the first glimpses of the aftermath, according to a Washington Post analysis. Blast analysts have cautioned against drawing conclusions too quickly given the underground nature of the impacts.Arab states fear they’ll pay a price if strikes on Iran prompt wider war Return to menuCAIRO — Arab governments were alarmed Sunday after the U.S. strikes on three Iranian nuclear sites overnight, and they urged swift de-escalation amid fears of becoming battlegrounds in a widening confrontation between the two adversaries.Persian Gulf states such as Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, which might have once cheered the elimination of Iran’s nuclear program by force, instead criticized the American intervention.This is an excerpt from a full story.
html:
President Donald Trump said in an announcement on social media that Iran and Israel had agreed to a ceasefire, ending what he said should be called the “12-day war.” He congratulated both countries, saying the conflict “could have gone on for years, and destroyed the entire Middle East.” There was no immediate corroborating announcement from either the Israeli or Iranian governments. In an earlier post on Truth Social, Trump downplayed an Iranian attack Monday on the forward headquarters for U.S. Central Command in Qatar, home to about 10,000 troops, as a “very weak response” by Tehran to U.S. strikes on key Iranian nuclear sites. The president said there were no deaths or injuries in the attack.

Live coverage contributors 49

  • Return to menu

    Vice President JD Vance on Fox News said President Donald Trump had been “working the phones constantly” over the past 12 days of war between Israel and Iran. Vance said the ceasefire was in the works when he left the White House for the broadcast but that the American objective was to ensure Iran could not build a nuclear weapon. “I actually think when we look back, we will say the twelve-day war was an important reset moment for the entire region,” he said.

  • Return to menu

    Camp Taji, which hosts U.S. service members in central Iraq, came under drone attack, according to two Iraqi officials. The extent of the damage or casualties was not immediately known.

  • Exclusive: Israel warned top Iranian general, officials amid June 13 strikes

    Return to menu

    In the hours after Israel launched its first wave of strikes against Iran on June 13, killing top military leaders and nuclear scientists, Israeli intelligence operatives launched a covert campaign to intimidate senior officials with the apparent aim of dividing and destabilizing Tehran’s theocratic regime, according to three people familiar with the operation.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Return to menu

    President Donald Trump said on social media that Iran and Israel have agreed to a ceasefire, ending what he said should be called the “12-day war.” He congratulated both countries, saying the conflict “could have gone on for years, and destroyed the entire Middle East.” There was no immediate corroborating announcement from either the Israeli or Iranian governments, and his announcement followed a streak of social media posts Monday evening in which he thanked Iran for giving the U.S. advance warning of a missile attack on a U.S. air base in Qatar, while also calling it a “very weak response” in retaliation for U.S. strikes on key Iranian nuclear facilities. A day ago, he floated the possibility of “regime change” in Iran in a late night post.

  • Oil prices plunge as Iran retaliates with attack on U.S. air base

    Return to menu

    Oil prices plunged on Monday afternoon as markets reacted to Iran’s decision to retaliate for the U.S. bombing by striking a military target in Qatar rather than trying to close the Strait of Hormuz.

    Some 20 percent of the world’s oil and gas flows through the narrow strait. Iran had threatened to try to close it to shipping traffic, a move that could send oil prices soaring and push prices at the pump in the United States above $4 per gallon.

  • Return to menu

    In a string of social media posts on Monday, President Donald Trump appeared to signal a de-escalation of tensions with Iran, writing that Tehran seems to have “gotten it all out of their ‘system’” with its telegraphed and limited attack on U.S. forces in Qatar, and encouraging Iran and Israel to seek “Peace and Harmony in the Region.” “CONGRATULATIONS WORLD, IT’S TIME FOR PEACE!” he wrote in one Truth Social message.

  • Return to menu

    President Donald Trump described Iran’s missile attack on a U.S. air base in Qatar as a “very weak response” in retaliation for U.S. strikes on key Iranian nuclear sites. Trump said on Truth Social Monday that Iran gave the U.S. early warning, which “made it possible for no lives to be lost, and nobody to be injured.”

  • Macron says ‘no legality to’ U.S. strikes on Iran

    Return to menu

    French President Emmanuel Macron on Monday diverged from other key U.S. allies, saying there was “no legality to” the U.S. strikes on Iran, even if France “shares the objective” of preventing Tehran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. “We have consistently believed this can only be achieved through diplomatic and technical means,” Macron said. Other officials emphasized that France had no role in the strikes or the planning.

    The Pentagon is not aware of any U.S. injuries or deaths resulting from Iran’s attack on Al-Udeid Air Base in Qatar, U.S. defense officials said, acknowledging the strike involved short-range and medium-range ballistic missiles.

  • Here’s what else to know

    Return to menu

    • President Donald Trump — who is slated to meet with his national security team Monday afternoon — raised the prospect of regime change in Tehran, undercutting the messaging from his top officials. He also continued to claim substantial damage to the nuclear facilities from U.S. strikes, without providing additional evidence. The International Atomic Energy Agency is assessing the damage.
    • The Israeli military launched “unprecedentedly powerful” strikes Monday against an expanded set of targets across Iran, the Israeli Defense Ministry said. Sirens also sounded across Israel on Monday morning as Iran launched another salvo. There were no immediate reports of casualties.
    • Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi met with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow. Russia has shied away from providing Tehran with military assistance as Israel continues to pound Iran’s nuclear and military infrastructure. Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Esmaeil Baqaei said Iran expects Russia to play an active role at a time of conflict between Tehran and Washington, citing a strategic partnership that Tehran and Moscow signed just months ago — which Moscow has sought to downplay since the conflict began. The meeting at the Kremlin was scheduled before the U.S. attacks on Iran.
    • Iranian Maj. Gen. Abdolrahim Mousavi, chief of the Iranian army’s Joint Staff, warned Washington that the strikes on its nuclear facilities were tantamount to invading the country and have given Tehran a “free hand” to “act against U.S. interests and its army,” according to Iran’s official Islamic Republic News Agency.
